ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:15): I would like to call this a bug in vim
624e7733d6f22d10bf4418778e64d37d (22:16): can you tell me a situation where you would use the -f flag?
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:16): mael: zope external editor
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:16): it's a nice utility
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:16): you click on a special link in your web browser
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): and download a little file
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): the browser starts zopeedit on that file
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): zopeedit spawns an editor (gvim -f)
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): waits for the editor to complete
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): and uploads your changes back into the zope web server
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:17): another option would be an external editor in mutt
7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:17): which is nice for those times when zope throws your changes away ;)
624e7733d6f22d10bf4418778e64d37d (22:18): via -f zopedit has an easy way to determine when vim ended?
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (22:18): without -f it sees that the child process died immediately and doesn't notice that it left a grandchild running
624e7733d6f22d10bf4418778e64d37d (22:20): hm.. would be my "first time" ;)
7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:24): is there a way to quit vim, but retain the history from that session to be resumed later?

298a07a2ed4800b42ea82a506714e120 (22:29): zack: if you need to undo, don't quit the vim process
7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:30): ipkiss: ok, that sucks. :(
298a07a2ed4800b42ea82a506714e120 (22:30): not so much, imho

7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:31): but oh well, i can work around that

7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:32): it's just too bad the the "session file" saves exactly the parts about my sessions that don't change, and not the parts that do

298a07a2ed4800b42ea82a506714e120 (22:32): you can still use a branch :)
298a07a2ed4800b42ea82a506714e120 (22:33): or trash your tree and check-out again, if your changes happen to be useless
7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:33): yeah. i could use a branch. but 'undoing' is really irritating.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (22:33): or just don't quit your session...

fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (22:34): zack: then be at a sane place. Relying purely on undo/redo is a great way to lose work.

7c6df72bc11c1195044e363222bf3f3b (22:41): i was a very windows-oriented person up until a few years ago.
